@wolfstudy I think we should include this in 2.6.2
@wolfstudy Please also onboard this fix in release 2.6.2

> @wolfstudy Please also onboard this fix in release 2.6.2

Sure, will process it.

I was running into some issues where there were timeouts in the Pulsar client application logs. The Pulsar brokers were restarting. This was happening in a load test and it seemed that the broker restarts made the problem worse.

To mitigate the issue, the brokers were recently configured to use zookeeperSessionExpiredPolicy=reconnect setting. The broker zookeeper timeout related settings are at the default values (zooKeeperSessionTimeoutMillis=30000, zooKeeperOperationTimeoutSeconds=30), since it seems odd that the Zookeeper interactions would take longer since the CPU consumption looks very low on zk in the load test. 

Now, we reran the load test and the brokers became unavailable. The logs were filled with this type of errors:
```
07:37:09.740 [pulsar-zk-session-watcher-5-1] ERROR org.apache.pulsar.zookeeper.ZooKeeperSessionWatcher - timeout expired for reconnecting, invoking shutdown service
07:37:11.740 [pulsar-zk-session-watcher-5-1] ERROR org.apache.pulsar.zookeeper.ZooKeeperSessionWatcher - timeout expired for reconnecting, invoking shutdown service
07:37:13.741 [pulsar-zk-session-watcher-5-1] ERROR org.apache.pulsar.zookeeper.ZooKeeperSessionWatcher - timeout expired for reconnecting, invoking shutdown service
07:37:15.741 [pulsar-zk-session-watcher-5-1] ERROR org.apache.pulsar.zookeeper.ZooKeeperSessionWatcher - timeout expired for reconnecting, invoking shutdown service
```
This is with `zookeeperSessionExpiredPolicy=reconnect`. Previously with the default setting (`zookeeperSessionExpiredPolicy=shutdown`), the broker would resume operations after a restart. Now all brokers in a 3 node cluster get unavailable.

The benefit of using `zookeeperSessionExpiredPolicy=reconnect` is that now it was possible to get a thread dump from the system when it got unavailable, although the broker didn't ever resume operations.

In the thread dump, there are quite a few hanging threads. Some stack traces are similar to what #8406 fixes. 
```
"ForkJoinPool.commonPool-worker-7" #1258 daemon prio=5 os_prio=0 tid=0x00007f67a09f9000 nid=0x50a waiting on condition [0x00007f676c258000]
   java.lang.Thread.State: WAITING (parking)
	at sun.misc.Unsafe.park(Native Method)
	- parking to wait for  <0x000000044ca60338> (a java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture$Signaller)
	at java.util.concurrent.locks.LockSupport.park(LockSupport.java:175)
	at java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture$Signaller.block(CompletableFuture.java:1707)
	at java.util.concurrent.ForkJoinPool.managedBlock(ForkJoinPool.java:3313)
	at java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture.waitingGet(CompletableFuture.java:1742)
	at java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture.get(CompletableFuture.java:1908)
	at com.github.benmanes.caffeine.cache.LocalAsyncLoadingCache$LoadingCacheView.get(LocalAsyncLoadingCache.java:400)
	at org.apache.pulsar.common.naming.NamespaceBundleFactory.getBundles(NamespaceBundleFactory.java:160)
	at org.apache.pulsar.broker.namespace.NamespaceService.getBundle(NamespaceService.java:192)
	at org.apache.pulsar.broker.namespace.NamespaceService.isTopicOwned(NamespaceService.java:913)
	at org.apache.pulsar.broker.namespace.NamespaceService.isServiceUnitOwned(NamespaceService.java:877)
	at org.apache.pulsar.broker.service.BrokerService.checkTopicNsOwnership(BrokerService.java:1359)
	at org.apache.pulsar.broker.service.persistent.PersistentTopic.subscribe(PersistentTopic.java:521)
```
Full thread dump of broker:
https://gist.github.com/lhotari/ba9c45cf4111a66f5e8960df4955bbf8
Online thread dump report: https://jstack.review/?https://gist.github.com/lhotari/ba9c45cf4111a66f5e8960df4955bbf8

The reason why I'm bringing this up in this issue is that a Zookeeper timeout exception in the broker logs can actually be caused by threads hanging in the broker. Hopefully #8406 gets also fixed in the upcoming Pulsar 2.6.2 version


UPDATE: I now noticed that there's an incoming PR #8304 (fix for #4635 which is also a deadlock).

Some of the Zookeeper related issues in the broker might get fixed by #8406 . I documented my experiences in https://github.com/apache/pulsar/issues/6259#issuecomment-719460964 . I haven't yet tested the fix since it was done about 24 hrs ago.
FYI, there's another related fix #8406 that was already merged.
There's another open PR #8304 which is also a fix for deadlocks in Broker (#4635).
I think #8304 is a more radical solution to the deadlocks that can occur in Pulsar brokers.

> Cool.
> Do you see improvements in the overall execution time?

@eolivelli 
I'm still investigating and experimenting. The `discard` and deletes isn't the root cause. I assume it will help.
My current assumption is that the build uses too much IO. The cache action pulls in almost 4GB m2 repository files for every single job. Because of that 4GB/jobs x 20 jobs = 80GB of data transferred total across all workflows of a PR.
The Azure disk IOPS rate limiting might simply be kicking in. The reason why the speed varies so much might be that the Github Runner implementation caches the VMs and if the rate limiting kicks in with a delay or it's over a longer time window, it might be a previous build has already used some of the IOPS quota.

I'll soon investigate why the m2 cache is almost 4GB. That's probably mostly a waste. The cache configuration needs optimization. I'll be modifying that and starting with an empty m2 cache.

In my experiment I also removed the config where unit tests are run inside a container apachepulsar/pulsar-build:latest. That image is hundreds of MBs and that also could be replaced with a more efficient solution. It seems that a few more unit tests fail when they are run on the Runner VM instead.

I'll continue experimenting to see how different settings impact the performance. Making the build easier to maintain is also my goal. I'll be using build matrix feature to spin off multiple jobs of a single type. The amount of workflows can be reduced. Build steps can be shared with local composite actions stored in .github/actions directory.
/pulsarbot run-failure-checks

There is some information about the IOPS limits in Azure: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/linux/optimization#unmanaged-storage-account-considerations 
and https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/disks-types#disk-comparison
It can be assumed that Azure storage accounts are shared across a lot of different type of Github repositories and their builds. 

@eolivelli It's the "noisy neighbor" problem that is the main issue, I guess. In Github Runner VMs the problem seems to be much worse that what a typical "noisy neighbor" problem is in public cloud environments. The 20k IOPS quota might be shared across a lot of other Github repository workflows and how can you impact that at all?
I wonder if it's possible to get the Github support to assign Apache Pulsar to a decicated storage account so that we don't have neighbors at all that could be noisy.

One possible strategy would be to detect if the VM has noisy neighbors and stop the job immediately. Perhaps a "bot" could restart the job in that case and assuming that the job execution would land on a different VM that doesn't have noisy neighbors.

It is also possible that it's the other PR builds that are the noisy neighbors. I hope to get some clarification from Github Actions support to find out how they allocate Azure storage accounts to Github repositories.

I noticed that there might be a way to get more IOPS out of the existing Github Runner VMs.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/linux/optimization#unmanaged-storage-account-considerations
> If you create a VM with unmanaged disks, make sure that you attach disks from storage accounts residing in the same region as your VM to ensure close proximity and minimize network latency. Each Standard storage account has a maximum of 20k IOps and a 500 TB size capacity.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/disks-types#disk-comparison 
> Standard SSD - Max IOPS - 6,000


In the Github Runner VMs, the root disk is a "managed disk" of the size of 84GB and there's an "unmanaged disk" of the size of 14GB, that is mounted at /mnt. 
These use different quotas. My assumption is that the root disk has 6k IOPS as the quota.
Based on the above information "Each Standard storage account has a maximum of 20k IOps", so this would mean that /mnt has 20k IOPS quota. They are most likely from different quotas. Since most accounts won't be consuming the /mnt disk quota, there will be a lot less noisy neighbors.

/mnt is currently only used for a 4GB swapfile. The total disk space is 14GB. The swapfile can be deleted so there will be 14GB workspace. I'll run an experiment where I set the working directory to something under /mnt to see this will help improve the performance. I'll also remove the "clean disk" step since that is causing a lot of IOPS being wasted. I think Github Actions should have different type of VMs available so that users wouldn't have to do such hacks to get more diskspace.

In the first experiment, I was trying to use "mount -o remount,[mount options] /" to disable discard and barrier mount options. However, remounting doesn't seem to have an impact on all mount options. I found a report from an Azure user that had experimented this. I added a comment in https://github.com/actions/virtual-environments/pull/1942#issuecomment-719917419 with references.
/pulsarbot run-failure-checks

@alexku7 The broker will call `getData` and `setData` for each `grantPermission` operation. If you have 3.5 topics and 2-3 calls for each topic. I think this will introduce almost 10,000 operations on the zookeeper, does this match your zookeeper's index?

There is a build-in schema registry in Pulsar. You can update your schema when the database schema is changed. From the consumer side, you can get the schema version of the schema. For example, the schema version changes from 1 to 2, this means version 1 is the old data structure and version 2 is the new data structure. So that you can make make a decision according to the different schema versions, this way, you need to upgrade the consumer first. For more details of the Pulsar schema, you can see http://pulsar.apache.org/docs/en/schema-get-started/

Another way is the DLQ that you have mentioned. You can store if the old data into the DLQ if needed. Of cause, if you don't want to maintain the old data you can acknowledge them directly.

@codelipenghui I am not wanting to aggregate. As you can see from the screenshot, some metrics are not being grouped under their `# TYPE` header. See `# TYPE pulsar_msg_backlog gauge` header, under that I can see 9 other metrics not related to that header. This happens in a few other places and metrics are scattered across the output.

Prometheus docs states "All lines for a given metric must be provided as one single group" - https://github.com/prometheus/docs/blob/master/content/docs/instrumenting/exposition_formats.md#grouping-and-sorting

Hello，@sijie
Basic function debugging, connect pulsar coredump

From the stack we can see the segmentation fault was caused by `boost::asio::ip::tcp::socket`'s constructor. I found some similar issues:
- https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45923885/boost-asio-io-service-multiple-objects-from-multiple-source-files-threads-cras
- https://github.com/mostphotos/beanstalkpp/pull/6

Could you give the version of boost dependencies by `ldd libpulsar.so`?

So i guess it will be 10.5k calls ?

For each partitions we have few sets of permissions (consume, produce or both)

So, I understand that it's normal to "kill" 40 gb disk space by  this load ?

Btw, what do you mean "zookeeper's index"
Assume.  I put large disks, how can i improve the zookeepers performance in order to prevent "timeouts" during this heavy operations ?

Thank you for the comment.
What you describe makes total sense.

My idea would be that the consumer does not need to be upgraded since it will just read the metadata inside the message and know what the tablename, structure and data he needs to write to.

From what I read, pulsar currently does not support multiple schemas on a topic so I would need to have one topic per domain of data produced.

The transaction buffer design had been changed, I closed this PR.

Good explanation for this issue on the slack from @addisonj 


Addison Higham  2 hours ago
is this in a single namespace? if so, then the reason for this is because it is all stored in single document, and because of the way the transaction log works, you are going to see a lot of churn with continuing to add to a single big document.
First off, what is the use case you are trying to solve for? Are these all to unique roles?
Second, you might consider using namespaces to work around this
Finally, if you want to support this easily today, you could implement your own authorization backend and use some alternative store and/or alternative way of defining all the calls. At some point, we expect to rework the build-in ACL implementation to not write to zookeeper

alex kurtser  1 hour ago
Thanks
Actually we have lot of namespaces were each one can have up to 500 topics and the permissions there are per topic , not per namespace.
IF all this information is stored in the single document, it make sens why we  see lot of write transactions.
I don;t know if we can implement now our own authorization back-end..
we will think how to change the design in order to find some workaround
Do you know about the ETA for the eliminating the using of zookkeeper for the permissions store ?
So I believe  , this is bad combination of the permissions storing model in the zookeeper with our per-topic RBAC design :(
Add a doc-required label as the broker config file is updated.
